snippet.textDisplay:
You should have stayed with the Constellations moving argument. If there were a "vanishing point" they were "shrinking into", then the whole constellation would get smaller. It doesn't. At times, they are only PARTIALLY covered by the horizon. But are still FULL SIZE. Therefore, they are not "shrinking" due to "flerspective".


Sunrise heading angles also fail miserably on the Flat Earth model. Especially in the southern hemisphere.


We KNOW the distance around the equator. Navigation requires it, and it's 24,901 statute miles. We also know the distance from the equator to the north pole, again needed for navigation to be remotely accurate. It's 6179 statute miles. We also know basic geometry says that the circumference of a circle with a radius of r is C = 2 π r. So the equator should be 38,824 statute miles....but it isn't. Or the distance from the equator to the north pole should be 3,963 statute miles....but it isn't.


Have your mom watch @CoolHardLogic videos on flat earth and geocentrism. He debunks the stupidity quite nicely (if a bit abrasively at times) and shows it in simple diagrams, graphs, and animations. If she's believing it because she's become a fundamentalist Christian literalist/Young-Earth creationist to try to be more "pious" before she passes, she won't accept ANYTHING rational as an argument though.......as she didn't reach her conclusions through rational thinking.
(Σ)
snippet.textOriginal:
You should have stayed with the Constellations moving argument.   If there were a "vanishing point" they were "shrinking into", then the whole constellation would get smaller.  It doesn't.  At times, they are only PARTIALLY covered by the horizon.  But are still FULL SIZE.  Therefore, they are not "shrinking" due to "flerspective".


Sunrise heading angles also fail miserably on the Flat Earth model.  Especially in the southern hemisphere.


We KNOW the distance around the equator.  Navigation requires it, and it's 24,901 statute miles.  We also know the distance from the equator to the north pole, again needed for navigation to be remotely accurate.  It's 6179 statute miles.  We also know basic geometry says that the circumference of a circle with a radius of r is C = 2 π r.   So the equator should be 38,824 statute miles....but it isn't.  Or the distance from the equator to the north pole should be 3,963 statute miles....but it isn't.


Have your mom watch @CoolHardLogic videos on flat earth and geocentrism.  He debunks the stupidity quite nicely (if a bit abrasively at times) and shows it in simple diagrams, graphs, and animations.  If she's believing it because she's become a fundamentalist Christian literalist/Young-Earth creationist to try to be more "pious" before she passes, she won't accept ANYTHING rational as an argument though.......as she didn't reach her conclusions through rational thinking.
(Σ)

If you believe the earth is flat, you'd fit right into some era in the past. Everyone believed the earth was flat back then, it was common knowledge. People back then were uneducated.
